field_edited_text.value:
VI. Development of Planning Objectives

After discussion of the findings and
implications of the study phase by
representatives of merchants’ groups and city
officials, planning objectives were developed to
provide guidelines for overcoming some of the
problems that were beginning to emerge.

The objectives were presented for discussion in
tabular form for ease of comprehension. Each
objective was accompanied by a list of
considerations that would be necessary in
achieving the objectives. They are summarized
below:

1. Functional Use

The objectives were to strengthen the retail
core, increase population density, provide for
city and other governmental activities of a
decentralized nature, and create open space for
Its aesthetic value.

Among the considerations suggested for
discussion were:

Contracting the retail area to shorten walking
distances

Removing all conflicting nonretail uses

Provision of sites for multi-family housing and
provision for residential units above new stores

Using air rights over existing commercial
structures for multi-family residences

Reserving sites for such facilities as libraries,
health and welfare centers and similar
governmental offices

Creating open space by demolishing blighted
buildings and by providing small courts
between stores in selected locations.

2. Traffic and Circulation

Objectives were to minimize traffic congestion,
improve access to retail cores, provide a
pedestrian-way system and improve loading and
unloading facilities.

Considerations suggested for discussion
included:

Traffic loops around the retail cores

Direct connecting links between retail cores and

major thoroughfares and expressways
Convenient access to public transit facilities

Use of public open space in the form of malls
or small areas in conjunction with pedestrian
pathways

Development of a system of serviceways giving
access to the back entrances of commercial
buildings.

3. Parking

Objectives were to provide adequate off-street
parking in convenient locations and in harmony
with other elements of the core areas, to relate
the needs of moving traffic to the use of streets
for parking purposes and to restrict on-street
parking space to short-term parking.

Considerations were related to distribution of
parking spaces, their type, financing, visual
appearance, and locational considerations and
included:

Large off-street parking areas on the edge or in

the middle of the retail ccres, depending on
circumstances

Surface lots or underground or above-ground
structures, depending on demand, availability
of land and financing, with consideration given
to assembling surface areas for later
development with structures

Various types of financing
Convenient and attractive design

Connections between pedestrian passageways
and parking areas

On-street parking limited to fringe areas
surrounding core and allowed only during
off-peak hours.

4. Visual Appearance

The objective was to create a visual
environment easily identifiable with each area
and related to a central design theme.

Considerations were:

Special types of lighting

19

Uniform sign system

Street furniture designed for its specific usé and
location

Coordinated color scheme for restoration and
rehabilitation

Coordinated landscaping

5. Design Theme
The objective was to achieve a coordinated and
unifying design theme for each retail core area.

Considerations included:

A central design theme to create a visual
environment readily identifiable and which
would have a unifying effect

Use of unique symbols signifying different
types of stores.

6. Public Markets

The objective was to develop the public
markets as focal points and attractions.
Considerations included:

More attractive facades and landscaping of
market buildings and sites

Six-day weekly operation and improved
shopping facilities

A merchants’ cooperative which could lease
premises and be responsible for maintenance,
promotion and merchandising

Redesign of market buildings to permit outdoor
operation in suitable weather

Use of market buildings as accommodation for
merchants forced to move because of
improvement program

7. Elimination of Blight

The objective was to demolish all structures
that could not be rehabilitated economically--
except buildings of historic or architectural
significance--and use the land for new facilities
in keeping with the improvement program.

Considerations suggested for discussion
included:
